questions.text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he fell from the top of the staircase at home. He reports pain in the neck as well as weakness of the upper extremities. He has hypertension well-controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. He is alert and immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Examination shows bruising and midline cervical tenderness. Neurologic examination shows diminished strength and sensation to pain and temperature in the upper extremities, particularly in the hands. Upper extremity deep tendon reflexes are absent. Strength, sensation, and reflexes in the lower extremities are intact. Anal sensation and tone are present. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the cause of this patient's neurologic examination findings?

choices.text: CT of the cervical spine with contrast
MRI of the cervical spine without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient who has sustained trauma, MR angiography of the neck is an appropriate imaging modality when clinical or radiological findings suggest an injury to blood vessels in the neck (e.g., carotid artery dissection, pseudoaneurysm). This patient is at lower risk for vascular injury, as he did not suffer any penetrating trauma. He also lacks clinical features that would suggest injury to the vertebral or carotid arteries (e.g., neurological deficits caused by a cortical or brainstem infarct). A different imaging modality is indicated for this patient with clinical features of a central cord syndrome, which is not known to be caused by a vascular etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

In a patient who has sustained trauma, CT angiography of the neck is an appropriate imaging modality when clinical or radiological findings suggest an injury to blood vessels in the neck (e.g., carotid artery dissection, pseudoaneurysm). This patient is at a lower risk for vascular injury as he did not suffer any penetrating trauma. He also lacks clinical features that would suggest injury to the vertebral or carotid arteries (e.g., neurological deficits caused by a cortical or brainstem infarct). A different imaging modality is indicated for this patient with clinical features of a central cord syndrome, which is not known to be caused by a vascular etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

CT with contrast may be appropriate for patients with myelopathy of suspected vascular origin (e.g., anterior spinal artery syndrome), as contrast can help define vascular structures. However, this patient likely has central cord syndrome from cervical hyperextension, not vascular infarction. In traumatic cervical myelopathy, CT of the cervical spine without contrast is indicated to identify fractures or dislocations of the cervical vertebrae; a contrast-enhanced CT scan is not recommended, since contrast and blood have similar Hounsfield units, and a contrast medium can obscure a possible cord hematoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Myelography may be considered in patients in whom the first-line diagnostic test is inconclusive or cannot be performed. However, it is not commonly performed as it has been largely replaced by less invasive and faster imaging modalities.

E) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the cervical spine may be indicated in a patient with traumatic myelopathy if the first-line diagnostic test cannot be performed or is unavailable. A different imaging modality is indicated in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Central cord syndrome most commonly occurs in older individuals with cervical spondylosis after acute hyperextension following a trauma, as seen in this patient. MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the first-line diagnostic test in patients with traumatic cervical myelopathy since it provides the best visualization of the soft tissue structures and can thus accurately delineate the extent of contusion or edema within the spinal cord. Documentation of the severity of spinal cord injury is important for follow-up and prognostication.

In addition to a non-contrast MRI, a non-contrast CT of the cervical spine may also be performed since a CT, which is more sensitive than MRI for bone pathology, can provide complementary information to the soft tissue findings obtained on MRI.
questions.hint: Bilateral upper extremity weakness with diminished pain and temperature sensation (particularly in the hands) is characteristic of a central cord syndrome at the level of the cervical spine. Strength and reflexes are intact in the lower extremities because the motor fibers supplying the legs run more laterally in the corticospinal tract than the motor fibers supplying the arms. The acute onset of symptoms following trauma indicates that traumatic myelopathy is the underlying etiology.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to his back during an altercation. He reports weakness and numbness of the lower extremities. He has no history of serious illness. On arrival, he is alert and cooperative. His pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm laceration on his back next to the vertebral column at the level of the T10 vertebra. Neurologic examination shows right-sided flaccid paralysis with a diminished vibratory sense ipsilaterally, decreased sensation to light touch at the level of his laceration and below, and left-sided loss of temperature and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in his right lower extremity and 2+ in his left lower extremity. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome can occur following a stab wound as a result of damage to the aorta. It presents with complete motor paralysis (damaged corticospinal tracts), loss of pain and temperature (damaged spinothalamic tracts), and autonomic dysfunction (hypotension, bowel, or bladder dysfunction) below the level of the lesion. Unlike this patient, the deficits in a patient with an anterior cord syndrome would typically occur bilaterally, while proprioception and vibratory sensation would be preserved (intact dorsal columns).
Image Description:

Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

B) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome can occur after trauma to the lumbar spine. The syndrome may present with sensory and motor deficits in both limbs as in this patient. However, the distribution of neurological deficits is variable, and does not follow a specific lateralization pattern, as seen here. Other clinical features associated with cauda equina syndrome, such as lower back pain radiating to the leg(s), weakness of plantar flexion (S1 and S2 lesions), and bladder or rectal sphincter paralysis (S2–S4 involvement), are also not present in this patient. Moreover, the knife wound is located above the level of the cauda equina, making cauda equina syndrome an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

C) CORRECT:

Brown-Séquard syndrome can occur after trauma to the spinal cord. In this patient, a right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord has resulted in right-sided flaccid paralysis (damaged right lateral corticospinal tract), as well as a right-sided loss of proprioception, tactile discrimination, and vibratory sense (damaged right dorsal column). Additionally, damage to the right spinothalamic tract has resulted in a left-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation. These symptoms are consistent with acute manifestations of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Within 1–2 weeks after the initial injury, patients typically develop an ipsilateral Babinski reflex and ipsilateral spastic paralysis. Bladder symptoms (e.g., incontinence) are generally not present, as there is only unilateral involvement of the descending autonomic fibers.

D) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome can occur following penetrating injury to the dorsal columns, or damage to the posterior spinal arteries. Patients would present with isolated loss of proprioception, vibratory sensation, and tactile discrimination. The posterior arteries are paired so interruption of a posterior spinal artery may only affect one side of the cord. Although this patient presents with asymmetric loss of light touch and vibratory sensation, the loss of both temperature and pinprick sensation are inconsistent with posterior cord syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome is the most common injury of the cervical spinal cord. The syndrome classically presents in the setting of a hyperextension injury in individuals with chronic cervical spondylosis, resulting in a disproportionately greater loss of motor function and sensation in the upper extremities when compared to the lower extremities. This patient, however, presents with loss of proprioception and vibration sense, which suggests damage to the dorsal column. The dorsal column is usually spared in a central cord lesion. Furthermore, a knife wound is unlikely to cause isolated damage to the central spinal cord.
questions.hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and some light-touch sensations, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The posterolateral corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 mL of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Muscle strength is 0/5 in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tabes dorsalis, which is the result of tertiary syphilis, affects the dorsal columns and manifests with an isolated loss of proprioception. Flaccid paralysis with pain and temperature deficits is typically not seen in tabes dorsalis. Furthermore, tabes dorsalis typically occurs after many years of infection with syphilis and proprioceptive deficits evolve slowly. The acute onset of this patient's symptoms makes tabes dorsalis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Anterior spinal artery syndrome (ASA syndrome) is a loss of function of the part of the spinal cord supplied by the anterior spinal artery, which includes the descending corticospinal tract fibers (resulting in bilateral flaccid paralysis and loss of deep tendon reflexes in the acute phase), the ascending spinothalamic tracts (causing bilateral pain/temperature sensation loss), and autonomic fibers (resulting in hypotension). The anterior spinal cord is at increased risk for infarction because it is supplied by the single anterior spinal artery, which has few collaterals. Therefore, significant blood loss, as seen in this patient, can lead to ischemic infarction of the anterior spinal cord.

In patients with ASA syndrome vibration and proprioception are typically preserved because the dorsal column, which is supplied by posterior spinal arteries, remains intact.
Image Description:

Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

C) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) usually manifests with ascending flaccid paralysis that develops over the course of hours to weeks. Patients may have a prodrome of painful sensations and typically have an antecedent viral or gastrointestinal illness such as Campylobacter enterocolitis. Although this patient has flaccid paralysis, her paralysis began without an ascending course or prodromal symptoms. Furthermore, in GBS, the patient is areflexic in all joints, and pain and temperature sensation are relatively preserved. This patient has 2+ reflexes in her upper extremities and has lost significant pain and temperature sensation, making GBS unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Séquard syndrome occurs when either the right or the left half of the spinal cord is damaged. Unlike this patient's bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and preserved proprioception, Brown-Séquard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral weakness and loss of proprioception, as well as pain and temperature deficits contralaterally.

E) INCORRECT:

Posterior spinal artery syndrome results in loss of proprioception, vibratory sensation, and diminished two-point discrimination at and below the level of the injury. This patient has preserved vibratory sensation as demonstrated by the tuning fork. In addition, the condition is not very common because the posterior cord is supplied by two posterior spinal arteries with collateral blood supply from reticulospinal arteries.
questions.hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and some light-touch sensation, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The anterior corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he fell off a ladder at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the ankles and 2+ in the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The cerebellum is supplied by the posterior circulation, and a stroke in this region can be due to dissection of the vertebral artery as a result of trauma. However, cerebellar stroke usually manifests with unilateral signs of ataxia, which this patient lacks. In addition, a cerebellar stroke would not explain this patient's bilateral motor weakness, hyperreflexia of the ankles, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

F) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.
questions.hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. During the last several days, she has had trouble urinating. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation. Her only medication is anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Knee and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome (CMS) is caused by damage to the spinal cord segments T12–L2 and can manifest with lower back pain, radicular pain, distal paresis, perianal numbness, and urinary incontinence. The onset of symptoms is typically sudden, whereas this patient's symptoms have developed gradually over 3 weeks. In addition, distal paresis in patients with CMS is usually symmetric, in contrast to this patient's asymmetric weakness. Finally, CMS is not associated with decreased sensation of the thighs.

B) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetric lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, bladder dysfunction, decreased anal tone, and severe back pain that radiates to lower limbs is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given this patient's history of breast cancer, spinal imaging including MRI is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome can result in weakness and urinary retention. However, the weakness associated with central cord syndrome is usually symmetric and more prominent in the upper extremities. In addition, patients with this condition often experience loss of pain and temperature sensation in dermatomes near the level of the spinal cord lesion. Finally, central cord syndrome does not typically cause radiculopathy or decreased perianal and thigh sensation.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome can result in unilateral lower extremity weakness and urinary retention. This condition is characteristically associated with ipsilateral diminished sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the spinal lesion, whereas this patient has unilateral radicular pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome classically results in symmetric loss of motor function and pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This patient has asymmetric symptoms, including unilateral radicular pain.
questions.hint: Two features specific to this patient's diagnosis are severe radicular pain and asymmetric weakness.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has quadriparesis as a result of a burst fracture of the cervical spine that occurred after a fall from his roof 1 month ago. He has urinary and bowel incontinence. He appears malnourished. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 104/60 mm Hg. Examination shows spasticity in all extremities. Muscle strength is decreased in proximal and distal muscle groups bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is absent below the neck. Sensation to vibration, position, and fine touch is normal bilaterally. Rectal tone is decreased. There is a 1-cm area of erythema over the sacrum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Occlusion of the posterior spinal artery
Damage to the anterior spinal artery
Injury to gray matter of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cavitation within the spinal cord or syringomyelia most commonly form within the central canal of the cervical spinal cord. Clinical features include a “cape-like”, bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper limbs. Extension of the syrinx into the ventral horn causes flaccid paraparesis of the upper extremities. The lower limbs are unaffected. This patient has symmetric spastic quadriparesis and hyperreflexia, which is inconsistent with syringomyelia.

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior spinal artery leads to infarction of the posterior spinal cord distal to the level of the injury (posterior cord syndrome). Clinical features include loss of proprioception, fine touch sensation, vibratory sensation, and two-point discrimination. Pain and temperature sensation and motor function are preserved. This patient's preserved vibration and fine touch sensation, as well as quadriparesis and absent pinprick sensation, are not consistent with posterior cord syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemi-transection of the spinal cord causes Brown-Séquard syndrome. Clinical features include ipsilateral spastic hemiparesis, loss of proprioception, and loss of vibratory sensation distal to the lesion. Hypotonic paralysis occurs at the level of the lesions, and contralateral pain and temperature sensation is preserved at the lesion but diminished distally starting about 2–3 dermatomes below the lesion. This patient's findings of symmetric bilateral neurological deficits and preserved vibration and fine touch sensation are not consistent with Brown-Séquard syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Occlusion of the anterior spinal artery leads to infarction of the ventral and lateral spinal cord distal to the level of the injury, which results in anterior cord syndrome (ACS). Clinical features of ACS include symmetric bilateral spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, and decreased pain and temperature sensation distal to the lesion. Vibration, proprioception, and fine touch are preserved because the dorsal columns are supplied by posterior spinal arteries.

Common causes of ACS include aortic surgery (e.g., aortic aneurysm repair), trauma (e.g., penetrating injury), hypotension (e.g., due to severe hemorrhage), and compression (e.g., due to tumors, cervical spondylosis, vertebral fractures).
Image Description:

Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the spinal cord gray matter results in damage to upper motor neuron axons, as well as dendrites and cell bodies of interneurons and lower motor neurons. Clinical features depend on the level of injury and which areas of the cord are affected. Motor deficits would include hyporeflexia at the level of gray matter injury. This patient's hyperreflexia and the presence of Babinski sign are not indicative of a lower motor neuron lesion.
questions.hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and fine touch sensation, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The anterior corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.

questions.text: Four hours after undergoing an open emergency surgery under general anesthesia for a bleeding abdominal aortic aneurysm, a 55-year-old man is unable to move both his legs. During the surgery, he had prolonged hypotension, which was corrected with IV fluids and vasopressors. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Prior to admission, his medications were hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient is conscious and oriented to place and person. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.0°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Normal temperature sensation in the extremities
Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pain and temperature sensations are carried by the spinothalamic tracts, which are located anterolaterally within the spinal cord. In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged, causing pain and temperature sensation to be lost.

B) INCORRECT:

Babinski sign, which is a feature of an upper motor neuron lesion, would eventually be present in ASA syndrome because of damage to the corticospinal tract. But Babinski reflex is usually not present initially because of spinal shock, and first appears typically 24 hours later.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of a normal bulbocavernosus reflex indicates the resolution of spinal shock. Sudden-onset paraplegia and autonomic dysfunction immediately after aortic surgery are highly suggestive of spinal shock during the acute phase of ASA syndrome. The bulbocavernosus reflex is normally absent during this phase.

D) INCORRECT:

Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk reflexes are features of an upper motor neuron lesion. Since corticospinal tracts are damaged in ASA syndrome, patients eventually develop hyperreflexia in all limbs below the level of the lesion after about a week. During the acute phase of ASA syndrome, though, deep tendon reflexes are usually lost as a result of spinal shock.

E) CORRECT:

In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged. The dorsal column, which receives its blood supply from the posterior spinal arteries, usually remains intact. Therefore, proprioception, pressure, and vibration senses are preserved in patients with ASA syndrome.
Image Description:

Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of paraparesis and autonomic dysfunction immediately after an aortic surgery, especially in the setting of intraoperative hypotension, is highly suggestive of anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome, as the artery that contributes to spinal cord perfusion (artery of Adamkiewicz) can be injured during aortic surgery.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressively worsening paresthesias in her upper limbs. She has accidentally burned her fingers on hot dishes several times. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Neurological examination shows absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation over the upper extremities and upper chest. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In syringomyelia, damage to the anterior horn cells by an expanding syrinx would cause features of lower motor neuron injury (e.g., hyporeflexia, flaccid paresis) at the level of the syrinx. Since the syrinx is most likely located at the level of the C5–T1 spinal nerves and the anterior horn cells that form the efferent arc of the biceps reflex are located at the level of the C5 and C6 spinal nerves, the patient is at risk of developing a decreased or absent rather than exaggerated biceps reflex. Features of upper motor neuron injury (e.g., hyperreflexia) can occur below the level of the syrinx due to damage to the upper motor neurons in the medial part of the lateral corticospinal tracts.

B) INCORRECT:

Syringomyelia does not affect cognition, and therefore, a decreased Mini-Mental State Examination score is not expected in this patient. Conditions associated with spinal cord involvement and altered cognition include subacute combined degeneration (due to vitamin B12 deficiency) and tabes dorsalis with paralytic dementia (due to syphilis).

C) INCORRECT:

The anal wink reflex is controlled by the pudendal nerve and nerve fibers arising from the sacral region, specifically at the level of S3 to S5. The absence of sacral sparing is characteristic of complete spinal cord injury. Patients with incomplete spinal cord injuries such as central cord syndrome typically have sacral sparing (i.e., an unaffected anal wink reflex or bulbocutaneous reflex) because the corticospinal fibers that innervate the anterior horn cells of the sacral segments are located in the lateral-most part of the corticospinal tract.

D) INCORRECT:

The trigeminal nerve provides innervation to the muscles of mastication and a unilateral lesion affecting the trigeminal nerve or its motor nucleus can manifest with a deviation of the jaw. The motor nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is located in the pons and is unlikely to be affected by the cervical syrinx. Only the spinal trigeminal nucleus (a sensory nucleus) extends into the cervical spinal cord (up to the C2 level).

E) CORRECT:

Expansion of the cervical syrinx damages the first-order oculosympathetic neurons, which are located just lateral to the central canal and carry descending sympathetic innervation from the hypothalamus to the ciliospinal center of Budge in the lateral horn. Damage to these neurons results in central Horner syndrome, which manifests with ptosis, i.e., drooping of the eyelid (because the superior tarsal muscle is sympathetically innervated), miosis, and anhidrosis.

As the syrinx expands, the patient will develop features of LMN injury at the syrinx's level (due to damage to the anterior horn cells) and features of UMN injury below the level of the syrinx (due to damage to the medial parts of the lateral corticospinal tract).
Image Description:

Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).
questions.hint: Dissociated sensory loss (dysesthetic pain and absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation) occurs as a result of the anterior white commissure compression. This finding in a cape-like distribution (upper extremities and upper chest) indicates a central cord syndrome of the cervicothoracic spinal cord (most likely at the level of the C5–T1 spinal nerves). The most likely cause of the condition in this patient is syringomyelia secondary to a whiplash injury.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a knife wound to his back. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm deep stab wound at the level of T9. He withdraws the right foot to pain but is unable to sense vibration or whether his right toe is flexed or extended. Sensation in the left leg is normal. Motor strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Rectal tone is normal. Which of the following spinal column structures was most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injury to the dorsal root ganglion at the level of T9 would lead to complete loss of sensory function in the corresponding T9 dermatome, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, this would not explain the loss of proprioception or vibration sensation in his right toe.

B) CORRECT:

Injury to the right posterior spinal artery leads to posterior spinal artery syndrome due to ischemia and subsequent infarction of the posterior column, which is directly supplied by this artery. Affected patients present with absent ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sensation below the level of the wound. In most cases, sensation to light touch is preserved. This patient's normal motor function and sensation to pain rule out any further injury to the corticospinal tract and spinothalamic tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Damage to the central spinal cord gray matter, which most typically results from hyperextension injury, spinal cord compression, and syringomyelia, leads to central cord syndrome (CCS). Unlike this patient, patients with CCS present with both sensory symptoms (e.g., loss of pain/temperature sensation bilaterally) and motor symptoms (weakness). CCS is most commonly caused by injuries in the cervical region, the involvement of the upper extremities is typically more prominent than in the lower extremities.

D) INCORRECT:

Injury to the lateral corticospinal tract would cause ipsilateral weakness below the level of the lesion. This patient instead presents with isolated sensory findings and full motor strength.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the artery of Adamkiewicz leads to anterior cord syndrome and can also be accompanied by urinary and fecal incontinence from infarction of the lumbosacral anterior spinal cord. Since an injury to this artery typically spares the dorsal columns, loss of proprioception and vibratory sense, as seen in this patient, would be unexpected.
questions.hint: A unilateral loss of proprioception and vibration with preservation of motor function and pain sensation indicates isolated damage to this patient's dorsal column.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed with a knife during an altercation. Physical examination shows a 4-cm stab wound on the right lateral border of the T1 spinous process. An MRI of the spinal cord shows damage to the area of the right lateral corticospinal tract at the level of T1. Further evaluation will most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Absence of left-sided proprioception below T1
Absence of right-sided temperature sensation below T1
Absence of left-sided fine touch sensation below T1
Absence of right-sided motor function below T1

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An absence of left-sided (contralateral to the injury) proprioception below T1 would be consistent with injury to the left dorsal column, which is unlikely given this patient's imaging findings of lateral corticospinal tract injury on the right side. Proprioception is transmitted via ascending sensory neurons in the dorsal column ipsilaterally, until decussation at the level of the medulla.

An absence of ipsilateral proprioception below the lesion would be expected if the right dorsal column were involved in this patient's injury.

B) INCORRECT:

An absence of right-sided temperature sensation below T1 would be most consistent with a left lateral spinothalamic tract injury at the level of T1. Sensory fibers from the lateral spinothalamic tract transmit input about pain and temperature and ascend two segments before decussating in the spinal cord and ascending contralaterally until they reach the sensory cortex. However, this patient's MRI shows damage to the right lateral corticospinal tract at T1, making this finding unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

The Babinski sign usually takes 1–2 weeks to appear after an upper motor neuron lesion occurs. This finding would be unlikely immediately following an acute injury. Furthermore, a Babinski sign would be expected ipsilateral to the injury (in this case, on the right side), as the upper motor neuron for the lateral corticospinal tract has been disrupted here and decussation of this tract occurs at a higher level.

D) INCORRECT:

An absence of left-sided fine touch below T1 would be expected with an injury to the left dorsal column, which is unlikely given this patient's imaging findings of lateral corticospinal tract injury on the right side. Fine touch is transmitted via ascending sensory neurons in the dorsal column ipsilaterally, until decussation at the level of the medulla.

E) CORRECT:

A right lateral corticospinal tract injury (e.g., partial Brown-Sequard syndrome) would result in the absence of ipsilateral motor function below injury level. The lateral corticospinal tract decussates at the level of the medulla. An injury distal to the decussation (e.g., at the level of T1) would, therefore, affect ipsilateral motor function below the level of the injury. In a full Brown-Sequard syndrome (e.g., hemisection of the spinal cord), there would also be ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception below T1 (dorsal column), ipsilateral Babinski sign (lateral corticospinal tract), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning two levels below the lesion (lateral spinothalamic tract).
questions.hint: This patient's mechanism of injury and imaging findings are consistent with a partial Brown-Sequard syndrome. The lateral corticospinal tract originates at the precentral gyrus and decussates at the level of the medulla.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to his back during an altercation. Examination shows a deep 4-cm laceration on his back next to the vertebral column at the level of the T10 vertebra. Neurologic examination shows right-sided flaccid paralysis with a diminished vibratory sense ipsilaterally, decreased sensation to light touch at the level of his laceration and below, and left-sided loss of temperature and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome can occur following a stab wound as a result of damage to the aorta. It presents with complete motor paralysis (damaged corticospinal tracts), loss of pain and temperature (damaged spinothalamic tracts), and autonomic dysfunction (hypotension, bowel, or bladder dysfunction) below the level of the lesion. Unlike this patient, the deficits in a patient with an anterior cord syndrome would typically occur bilaterally, while proprioception and vibratory sensation would be preserved (intact dorsal columns).
Image Description:

Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

B) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome can occur after trauma to the lumbar spine. The syndrome may present with sensory and motor deficits in both limbs as in this patient. However, the distribution of neurological deficits is variable, and does not follow a specific lateralization pattern, as seen here. Other clinical features associated with cauda equina syndrome, such as lower back pain radiating to the leg(s), weakness of plantar flexion (S1 and S2 lesions), and bladder or rectal sphincter paralysis (S2–S4 involvement), are also not present in this patient. Moreover, the knife wound is located above the level of the cauda equina, making cauda equina syndrome an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

C) CORRECT:

Brown-Séquard syndrome can occur after trauma to the spinal cord. In this patient, a right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord has resulted in right-sided flaccid paralysis (damaged right lateral corticospinal tract), as well as a right-sided loss of proprioception, tactile discrimination, and vibratory sense (damaged right dorsal column). Additionally, damage to the right spinothalamic tract has resulted in a left-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation. These symptoms are consistent with acute manifestations of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Within 1–2 weeks after the initial injury, patients typically develop an ipsilateral Babinski reflex and ipsilateral spastic paralysis. Bladder symptoms (e.g., incontinence) are generally not present, as there is only unilateral involvement of the descending autonomic fibers.

Key learning point: Brown-Séquard syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord, causing ipsilateral paralysis and loss of proprioception with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome can occur following penetrating injury to the dorsal columns, or damage to the posterior spinal arteries. Patients would present with isolated loss of proprioception, vibratory sensation, and tactile discrimination. The posterior arteries are paired so interruption of a posterior spinal artery may only affect one side of the cord. Although this patient presents with asymmetric loss of light touch and vibratory sensation, the loss of both temperature and pinprick sensation are inconsistent with posterior cord syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome is the most common injury of the cervical spinal cord. The syndrome classically presents in the setting of a hyperextension injury in individuals with chronic cervical spondylosis, resulting in a disproportionately greater loss of motor function and sensation in the upper extremities when compared to the lower extremities. This patient, however, presents with loss of proprioception and vibration sense, which suggests damage to the dorsal column. The dorsal column is usually spared in a central cord lesion. Furthermore, a knife wound is unlikely to cause isolated damage to the central spinal cord.
questions.hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and some light-touch sensations, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The posterolateral corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.

questions.text: You are seeing a 47-year-old man in the emergency department who presents with urinary and fecal incontinence for the past 6 hours. Earlier today, he fell off a ladder at a construction site, injuring his back and thighs, but did not seek medical attention at that time. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C, pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. On examination, there is tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ at the ankles and 2+ at the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a distended bladder. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

B) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).

Key learning point: Conus medullaris syndrome presents with sudden bladder and bowel dysfunction, symmetric lower limb weakness, and mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs due to injury at the distal spinal cord.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.

questions.text: Four hours after you perform an open emergency surgery under general anesthesia for a bleeding abdominal aortic aneurysm, a 55-year-old man is unable to move both of his legs. During the procedure, he experienced prolonged hypotension, which was managed with IV fluids and vasopressors. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Prior to admission, his medications were hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He is conscious and oriented to place and person. His temperature is 37.7°C, pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. On examination, muscle strength in the lower extremities is 1/5. Which one of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation?

choices.text: Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk.
Normal temperature sensation in the extremities.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged. The dorsal column, which receives its blood supply from the posterior spinal arteries, usually remains intact. Therefore, proprioception, pressure, and vibration senses are preserved in patients with ASA syndrome.

Key learning point: In anterior spinal artery syndrome, proprioception, vibration, and pressure senses are preserved because the dorsal columns remain intact, while motor function and pain/temperature sensation are lost below the lesion.
Image Description:

Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk reflexes are features of an upper motor neuron lesion. Since corticospinal tracts are damaged in ASA syndrome, patients eventually develop hyperreflexia in all limbs below the level of the lesion after about a week. During the acute phase of ASA syndrome, though, deep tendon reflexes are usually lost as a result of spinal shock.

C) INCORRECT:

Pain and temperature sensations are carried by the spinothalamic tracts, which are located anterolaterally within the spinal cord. In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged, causing pain and temperature sensation to be lost.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of a normal bulbocavernosus reflex indicates the resolution of spinal shock. Sudden-onset paraplegia and autonomic dysfunction immediately after aortic surgery are highly suggestive of spinal shock during the acute phase of ASA syndrome. The bulbocavernosus reflex is normally absent during this phase.

E) INCORRECT:

Babinski sign, which is a feature of an upper motor neuron lesion, would eventually be present in ASA syndrome because of damage to the corticospinal tract. But Babinski reflex is usually not present initially because of spinal shock, and first appears typically 24 hours later.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of paraparesis and autonomic dysfunction immediately after an aortic surgery, especially in the setting of intraoperative hypotension, is highly suggestive of anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome, as the artery that contributes to spinal cord perfusion (artery of Adamkiewicz) can be injured during aortic surgery.

questions.text: One hour after surgical repair of a thoracic aortic aneurysm, a 70-year-old man develops severe pain at the thoracolumbar junction along with weakness and numbness in both legs. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.0°C, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. On examination, there is decreased sensation to pain and temperature below the level of the umbilicus. Muscle strength in the lower extremities is 1/5. Proprioception and vibration sense are preserved in both lower extremities. Sensation and motor function in the upper extremities, chest, and back are intact. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome affects the dorsal columns. It would manifest as a loss of proprioception, fine touch, and vibration sense below the level of the lesion, with preserved muscle strength and pain and temperature sensation, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome (ACS) which is caused by damage to the anterior ⅔ of the spinal cord, manifests bilaterally, with lower motor neuron deficit at the level of the lesion (anterior horn damage), and decreased pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract damage) and upper motor neuron deficit (lateral corticospinal tract damage) below the level of the lesion. In ACS, proprioception and vibration sense are preserved because the posterior spinal arteries provide blood supply to the dorsal columns. The thoracolumbar segment of the spinal cord is a watershed area and is, therefore, the most common site of infarction, as seen here.

ACS may occur as a complication of an aortic aneurysm itself or iatrogenically during the repair of the aneurysm (due to damage to the anterior spinal artery and/or artery of Adamkiewicz). Other causes of ACS include trauma (e.g., penetrating injury), hypotension (e.g., from severe hemorrhage), and compression (e.g., tumors, cervical spondylosis).

Key learning point: Anterior cord syndrome causes bilateral motor paralysis and loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion, with preserved proprioception and vibration sense, typically due to anterior spinal artery infarction.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome (CCS) can manifest as bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (damage to the decussating fibers of the spinothalamic tract at the anterior white commissure) and bilateral paresis of the extremities (damage to lateral corticospinal tracts), as seen here. However, the paresis is usually worse in the upper extremities (especially the hands) when compared to the lower extremities (upper extremity tracts are more medial than lower extremity tracts). Moreover, CCS is commonly associated with pain and temperature loss in a “cape-like” distribution across the upper back and down the posterior upper extremities, which is not seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal epidural hematoma (SEH) can cause acute spinal cord compression and manifest as back pain and lower extremity weakness and numbness, as seen in this patient. However, SEH typically occurs following puncture of the dura mater that causes damage to the vertebral venous plexus (e.g., following lumbar puncture, after pulling a dural catheter) rather than following an aortic aneurysm repair.

E) INCORRECT:

Brown-Séquard syndrome occurs as a result of hemisection of the spinal cord and manifests as an ipsilateral loss of proprioception, fine touch, and vibration sense (dorsal column damage), contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract damage), ipsilateral lower motor neuron deficit at the level of the lesion (anterior horn damage), and ipsilateral upper motor neuron deficit below the level of the lesion (corticospinal tract damage). This is not consistent with the bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and bilateral weakness in lower extremities seen here. Moreover, this patient's proprioception and fine touch are intact bilaterally.
questions.hint: This patient may also experience bowel and bladder dysfunction due to bilateral damage to the lateral horns of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in his lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. Over the past week, he has also noticed decreased sensation around his buttocks and inner thighs, along with increased difficulty urinating. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer two years ago and received radiation therapy. Neurologic examination reveals reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; findings on the right are normal. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but squeeze tone is reduced. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.

Key learning point: Cauda equina syndrome presents with asymmetric lower limb weakness, saddle anesthesia, decreased reflexes, bladder dysfunction, and reduced anal sphincter tone, often due to compression below the L2 vertebral level.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: You are seeing a 20-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to his back during an altercation. On examination, there is a deep 4-cm laceration on his back adjacent to the vertebral column at the level of T10. Neurologic examination reveals right-sided flaccid paralysis and diminished vibratory sense on the same side, decreased sensation to light touch at and below the level of the laceration, and left-sided loss of temperature and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome is the most common injury of the cervical spinal cord. The syndrome classically presents in the setting of a hyperextension injury in individuals with chronic cervical spondylosis, resulting in a disproportionately greater loss of motor function and sensation in the upper extremities when compared to the lower extremities. This patient, however, presents with loss of proprioception and vibration sense, which suggests damage to the dorsal column. The dorsal column is usually spared in a central cord lesion. Furthermore, a knife wound is unlikely to cause isolated damage to the central spinal cord.

B) CORRECT:

Brown-Séquard syndrome can occur after trauma to the spinal cord. In this patient, a right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord has resulted in right-sided flaccid paralysis (damaged right lateral corticospinal tract), as well as a right-sided loss of proprioception, tactile discrimination, and vibratory sense (damaged right dorsal column). Additionally, damage to the right spinothalamic tract has resulted in a left-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation. These symptoms are consistent with acute manifestations of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Within 1–2 weeks after the initial injury, patients typically develop an ipsilateral Babinski reflex and ipsilateral spastic paralysis. Bladder symptoms (e.g., incontinence) are generally not present, as there is only unilateral involvement of the descending autonomic fibers.

Key learning point: Brown-Séquard syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord, causing ipsilateral paralysis and loss of proprioception with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome can occur after trauma to the lumbar spine. The syndrome may present with sensory and motor deficits in both limbs as in this patient. However, the distribution of neurological deficits is variable, and does not follow a specific lateralization pattern, as seen here. Other clinical features associated with cauda equina syndrome, such as lower back pain radiating to the leg(s), weakness of plantar flexion (S1 and S2 lesions), and bladder or rectal sphincter paralysis (S2–S4 involvement), are also not present in this patient. Moreover, the knife wound is located above the level of the cauda equina, making cauda equina syndrome an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome can occur following a stab wound as a result of damage to the aorta. It presents with complete motor paralysis (damaged corticospinal tracts), loss of pain and temperature (damaged spinothalamic tracts), and autonomic dysfunction (hypotension, bowel, or bladder dysfunction) below the level of the lesion. Unlike this patient, the deficits in a patient with an anterior cord syndrome would typically occur bilaterally, while proprioception and vibratory sensation would be preserved (intact dorsal columns).

E) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome can occur following penetrating injury to the dorsal columns, or damage to the posterior spinal arteries. Patients would present with isolated loss of proprioception, vibratory sensation, and tactile discrimination. The posterior arteries are paired so interruption of a posterior spinal artery may only affect one side of the cord. Although this patient presents with asymmetric loss of light touch and vibratory sensation, the loss of both temperature and pinprick sensation are inconsistent with posterior cord syndrome.
questions.hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and some light-touch sensations, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The posterolateral corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with acute onset of low back pain radiating to both legs, progressive bilateral leg weakness, and urinary incontinence developing over 8 hours. Physical examination shows symmetrical bilateral weakness that is greater distally than proximally in the lower extremities, hyperreflexia, and bilateral perianal numbness. Pain and temperature sensation are diminished in the lower extremities and remain intact in the upper extremities. What is the most likely anatomical location of the lesion?

choices.text: Posterior spinal cord at L3–L4 level
Central spinal cord at L1-L2 level
Anterior spinal cord at L1-L2 level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome causes bilateral loss of proprioception and sense of vibration, but motor function is preserved. Motor weakness and early bladder dysfunction are not consistent with isolated posterior column involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome typically affects the upper extremities more than lower extremities and does not cause the specific pattern of bilateral perianal numbness and early bladder incontinence characteristic of sacral segment involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome typically manifests with a gradual onset, asymmetrical presentation, and areflexic flaccid paresis. Late-onset urinary retention rather than early incontinence and saddle anesthesia pattern are more characteristic than the symmetrical bilateral findings seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Conus medullaris syndrome affects the sacral and coccygeal spinal segments at vertebral levels T12–L2. The sudden onset, symmetrical bilateral presentation, hyperreflexic distal paresis, early bladder incontinence, and characteristic perianal numbness with sensory dissociation are classic features of conus medullaris syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome causes bilateral motor paralysis and loss of pain and temperature sensation, but it does not specifically cause the symmetrical bilateral perianal numbness and hyperreflexia pattern seen in this patient. Furthermore, early bladder incontinence is not a characteristic of anterior cord syndrome.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling down stairs a few hours ago. She reports difficulty gripping objects with both hands and states that her legs feel weak. She denies any change in sensation. Examination reveals 3/5 strength in bilateral upper extremities and 4/5 strength in bilateral lower extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome typically manifests with bilateral loss of temperature and pain sensation below the lesion level due to spinothalamic tract damage, but this patient denies sensory changes.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Central cord syndrome classically manifests with bilateral motor weakness that is more pronounced in the upper extremities than the lower extremities due to the anatomical arrangement of corticospinal tract fibers, with arm fibers located more centrally and leg fibers distributed laterally.

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome primarily affects the dorsal columns, causing bilateral loss of vibration, fine touch, and proprioceptive sensation below the lesion level, but this patient denies any sensory changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Séquard syndrome involves hemisection of the spinal cord, causing characteristic unilateral motor weakness and sensory loss patterns, including contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, but this patient has bilateral symmetrical weakness and denies sensory changes.

E) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with bilateral symmetrical perianal numbness, early onset bladder and bowel incontinence, and lower back pain with radicular symptoms. This patient has bilateral weakness that is more prominent in the upper extremities than in the lower extremities, and she denies sensory changes.

questions.text: One hour after undergoing a surgical repair of a thoracic aortic aneurysm, a 70-year-old man experiences severe pain at the thoracolumbar junction and weakness and numbness in both legs. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pain and temperature below the level of the umbilicus. Muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Proprioception and vibration sense are normal in both lower extremities. Sensation and motor function in the upper extremities, chest, and back are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leriche syndrome (i.e., aortoiliac occlusive disease) is caused by peripheral artery disease at the level of the aortic bifurcation or bilateral occlusion of the iliac arteries. This condition manifests as the triad of thigh/hip claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent/diminished femoral pulses, which this patient does not have. Moreover, this patient presents with severe thoracolumbar pain, lower extremity numbness, and lower extremity muscle weakness, which would not be expected in Leriche syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome (ACS) which is caused by damage to the anterior ⅔ of the spinal cord, manifests bilaterally, with lower motor neuron deficit at the level of the lesion (anterior horn damage), and decreased pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract damage) and upper motor neuron deficit (lateral corticospinal tract damage) below the level of the lesion. In ACS, proprioception and vibration sense are preserved because the posterior spinal arteries provide blood supply to the dorsal columns. The thoracolumbar segment of the spinal cord is a watershed area and is, therefore, the most common site of infarction, as seen here.

ACS may occur as a complication of an aortic aneurysm itself or iatrogenically during the repair of the aneurysm (due to damage to the anterior spinal artery and/or artery of Adamkiewicz). Other causes of ACS include trauma (e.g., penetrating injury), hypotension (e.g., from severe hemorrhage), and compression (e.g., tumors, cervical spondylosis).

C) INCORRECT:

Brown-Séquard syndrome occurs as a result of hemisection of the spinal cord and manifests as an ipsilateral loss of proprioception, fine touch, and vibration sense (dorsal column damage), contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract damage), ipsilateral lower motor neuron deficit at the level of the lesion (anterior horn damage), and ipsilateral upper motor neuron deficit below the level of the lesion (corticospinal tract damage). This is not consistent with the bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and bilateral weakness in lower extremities seen here. Moreover, this patient's proprioception and fine touch are intact bilaterally.

D) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome (CCS) can manifest as bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (damage to the decussating fibers of the spinothalamic tract at the anterior white commissure) and bilateral paresis of the extremities (damage to lateral corticospinal tracts), as seen here. However, the paresis is usually worse in the upper extremities (especially the hands) when compared to the lower extremities (upper extremity tracts are more medial than lower extremity tracts). Moreover, CCS is commonly associated with pain and temperature loss in a “cape-like” distribution across the upper back and down the posterior upper extremities, which is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome affects the dorsal columns. It would manifest as a loss of proprioception, fine touch, and vibration sense below the level of the lesion, with preserved muscle strength and pain and temperature sensation, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation.

F) INCORRECT:

Spinal epidural hematoma (SEH) can cause acute spinal cord compression and manifest as back pain and lower extremity weakness and numbness, as seen in this patient. However, SEH typically occurs following puncture of the dura mater that causes damage to the vertebral venous plexus (e.g., following lumbar puncture, after pulling a dural catheter) rather than following an aortic aneurysm repair.
questions.hint: This patient may also experience bowel and bladder dysfunction due to bilateral damage to the lateral horns of the spinal cord.
